Test writing ideology Test should be worth 20% of your grade 32 MCQs targeting specific concepts and 4 FRQs, one for each unit just testing solving ability MCQs are SPECIFIC and hit one concept as the MAIN PIECE What makes the test difficult? Exp&Logs --> CONTENT. Inv Functions, a lot of properties, function comp, a lot of stuff that needs to be tested for means you get PUNISHED if you don't have enough breadth Writing hard test strat --> Test for breadth and make sure everything is tested, use MCQs to test for knowledge, evaluation questions that test log properties Rationals --> asymptotes and graphing, the rational graph has a lot of key details Writing hard test strat --> graphing problems and conceptual ones that target each key feature Radicals --> simplification, solving with domain restriction and absolute values Writing hard test strat --> a lot of FRQs around simplification Series and Sequences --> n/n+1, applying formulas Uniform motion when? How do you simplify rational, radical, exponential, and log equations? You should know the simplified form of each! Rationals Do you know how to find the LCD of rational functions?
Do you know how to solve Complex Rational Equations? Do you know how to find holes, asymptotes, domain/range, and other key features on a rational graph? Do you know how to calculate asymptotes? Radicals
Do you know how to solve double radical equations?
Do you know your Terminology? (index, radicand, etc.)
Do you know the Radical Properties? Exponentials
Do you know the Exponential Properties?
Do you know how to solve exponential equations using Exponential One to One, U-sub, and Logarithmic methods?
Do you know the key features of exponential graphs? Do you know the domain restrictions of exponential graphs? Logs
Do you know the Log Properties?
Do you know how to solve log equations using Logs One-to-One and Rewriting as Exponential?
Do you know the domain restrictions of the log function itself (see the note in Log Properties)?
Do you know the key features of log graphs? Sequences and Series
Do you know the terminology?
Can you Recognize, Describe, and Continue sequences?
Do you know the formulas for Arithmetic Series and Geometric Series?
Do you understand Infinite Sums and when a geometric series converges? General Functions
Do you know how to find the inverse of a function?
Do you know how to perform function composition? Throwing out some ideas here... Absolute hardest problems Double complex rational equation (E.g ) problems with domain-restricted solutions Log problems with exponents and change of base black magic to simplify Double radical problems with absolute value Series word problemWarning These are AI generated slop, may not have an actual answer yet! WIP. Test writing ideology Test should be worth 20% of your grade, around 100 points (3x quiz content) 1/3 of the test should be MCQs to test knowledge 2/3 of the test should be applying each and every formula we know Start by writing the formula questions, then go back and identify knowledge gaps and fill those in

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/getting-.description:
Tags: #to-code-a-robot #frc #coding Date: 2025-05-22Welcome to FRC! This section is a basic start to coding in FRC, and getting vital tools set up, like: Phoenix Tuner X: Diagnosis and Tuning tool for motors WPIlib: core library of all code WPIlib editor: core IDE REVlib: debugging and flashing Neo motors Git and Github: advanced version history. By the end of this section, you should be able to install every tool, setup the basic environment, and create your first project from a template!
Installing the Tools
Navigating the IDE

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/installi.title: Installing the Tools
to-code-a-robot/getting-started/installi.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-05The most important tool to download is WPIlib's IDE (Integrated Development Environment) so you can actually write code on a robot.
WPIlib download After downloading the ISO file, right click it to mount the disk image. Then, run the WPIlib Installer. You may need to run as administrator or unblock it via "Properties" if Windows Defender "protects" your computer. Then, follow the instructions in the installer, but make sure to install VS code along with the rest of the tools. The installer will extract and help download the rest of the files. After following these steps, you should be able to find and run WPIlib VS Code 2025, which is the IDE you'll be using. While you can use other IDEs like Neovim, it's highly recommended to use the bundled VS code for ease of use and to avoid issues later on.
PathPlanner is a tool used to draw and plan out autonomous paths and implement them in code easily, it's vital for anything related to autonomous - you can download it off the Microsoft Store here.
Phoenix Tuner X is a tuning software to help tune and debug motors. You can download this from the Microsoft Store. Latest firmware for specific motors can be found on their GitHub page.
The REVlib Hardware Manager is used to debug and flash NEO Brushless motors - you can download it here.
Follow this tutorial or just click the Git icon in the sidebar and download from there.
You should make an account on GitHub as well.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-an.title: Git and Github Intro
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-an.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12
Here's a quick 100 second intro to getting started with Git. Git is simply put, advanced version control. You make some edits, make a snapshot (a commit) of your code, so when you realize you made a massive mistake, you can revert and go back to that version. Another benefit of Git is the ability to make branches - you can branch off of stable working code, add and test a new feature, then merge it back into the stable branch. This is incredibly useful when working on a big project with multiple people: you can independently work on separate features. However, Git by itself is only for local use, to share and work online, you need to use GitHub to put your git workspace online. Tldr Git: Local branch & version control Github: Puts git work online for collaboration and backup (plus some additional features for collaboration)
Git and Github work with repositories, or codebases: the repo we will be using is this one: https://github.com/TASRobotics/RaidOne-2026-Offseason (ask Jared for access if you don't have it already).

to-code-a-robot/getting-started/navigati.title: Navigating the IDE
to-code-a-robot/getting-started/navigati.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Tip Customize!!! Obviously, go ahead and customize your IDE setup - WPIlib VScode is VScode but with additional features, so you can do all the VScode things like download plugins and change your editor to light mode (if you woke up and chose violence). You'll be looking at this screen for a long, long time so do whatever you need to be happy with it (no judgement (except if you use light mode, everyone except for Jard will judge you)) Now that you've finished downloading WPIlib, you should learn how to create projects and use the command palette. You can access all commands using the shortcut Ctrl + Shift + P, but if you only want to see WPIlib based commands you can click the WPIlib logo This brings up a list of commands - the most important ones are build robot code and deploy robot code. Building the code checks it for errors, and deploying the code deploys it to the robot.
In the sidebar, there's also a WPIlib logo, and when you click it it shows the vendor dependencies. Vendor dependencies (vendordeps) are used to add additional function on top of default WPIlib function, such as CTRE Phoenix's libraries, which add motion magic (motion profiles). Go into the command palette and create a new project. When you get to the project creation screen, select the template option, then java, then "Command Robot Skeleton (Advanced)". This gives you a virtually blank slate to start from. Follow the rest of the directions (team number for R1 is 8503) to make the project!
Now, you're ready to move into Git and Github and start doing actual hands-on work.

Unfortunately, a lot of this will have to be content because you simply need the knowledge here before you can apply it in a real scenario - feel free to skim through this and go straight into coding a subsystem.By the end of this lesson, you should be able to understand the fundamentals of programming and understand the Command-Based system that we follow.

Being good at Git is a simple but vital skill in order to be able to do work - it shouldn't take too long to learn, but not learning the basics will waste your entire season. Also, the hands-on learning starts here! Please follow along and do the tasks to actually learn them.By the end of this lesson, you should be able to connect your repository to git and github, use vital git commands, clone from projects on the internet, create branches, and merge branches with and without pull requests.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/branch.title: Branches
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/branch.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Now, all you've been doing is working on the main branch, which is bad coding practice! Main is only for working, tested code. That's why you should branch off of main to test specific features. It also helps to keep others' broken code (and also your broken code) from messing up other people's code.
So, now that you now why we branch, make a branch yourself with your name using the git branch command (or again, you can use the GUI/command palette). Then inside your new branch, create a new blank template project. (see Creating your first project). This is now your branch, and it's where you'll be doing all your work. Now that you have your own branch, you might be wondering how we actually merge back into main. Merging is something you'll have to do a lot of, and you can do this via the git merge command. By merging, you'll create a new commit, and that commit will have two branches' code together.
However, you might have merge conflicts, which you MUST always resolve. Merge conflicts are pretty simple - you go through each file that has a conflict and select the code segment you want to keep. It's too hard to explain it in writing so here's a video tutorial: Video tutorial Usually, you should use the three-way editor which is a lot faster and simpler to use. It's a little hard to test for merge conflicts in a general sense, so I'll go through and make some manually when you start working on more complicated code.

to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-co.title: Git Commands
to-code-a-robot/working-in-a-team/git-co.description:
Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-12Sometimes, you might find it easier to use the terminal rather than any GUI (graphical interface) to do Git work - some commands can only be done in the terminal! Open up a terminal within VScode via Ctrl + ` (backtick) or via the command palette. You may find it useful to change your terminal to Git Bash instead of Powershell for some commands. First things first: configure git via the Git Config command inside the terminal
(See here) Make sure to set it to the same username and email you use for GitHub! By configuring git, you tell git/github who you are, and what email address/user name to sign commits with. The first step to starting work is to clone (copy) the repository you want to work with.
You could probably create the repo first and push it online for local projects, but since the training repository already exists, use git clone on the training repo. Google/ChatGPT the answer yourself! Get used to doing a lot of googling and reading docs - you'll have to do this a lot during the season since there'll be a bunch you don't know.
Need help? https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/creating-and-managing-repositories/cloning-a-repository?platform=windows&tool=webui Git clone with clone everything - branches, history, etc. so don't worry about having to clone individual branches.After configuration and cloning, you can use the GUI if you like it better (some things, like resolving merge conflicts are disgusting in terminal). Let's start doing actual work: make a couple edits in the default README.md file and notice how the changes are untracked.
You have two options if you want to commit these changes (save/take a snapshot): you can stage specific files, or you can commit them all at once. Independently staging them has the benefit of being able to make small changes. However, in this case you can just commit - write a commit message in imperative tense (e.g add some text to README) and hit the fat commit button. Important Having good commit messages is extremely important when people want to see what you changed. The commit message should be in imperative tense: "If this commit is applied, it will ..." Also, make small commits so you can revert to more specific changes. While it seems really nitpicky to use imperative tense, when you're going through 600 commits you really want to be able to identify what specific changes you made instead of only being able to see "change some smol speed sturff". Some programmers have really bad habits and debugging their code sucks because of it. Now, you after you've made a commit, your job isn't done yet! You now have to push it online so others can see it. You can either click the sync button, or within terminal run git push to push your changes online. Something else to note is that Git doesn't automatically pull changes either - if someone made some changes, you'll have to sync or use git pull first.You can also push your changes online during the commit via the drop down menu.

to-code-a-robot/programming-basics/advan.title: Advanced Programming I - Command Based Paradigm
to-code-a-robot/programming-basics/advan.description: Tags: #frc #coding #to-code-a-robot Date: 2025-06-15very very very important. Now we move into more FRC-specific lessons - the past ones were more general and could be applied to multiple other languages.Command-based programming is the single most important concept for FRC programming. Before command-based programming existed, we had timed programming, which functioned similar to VEX - you would sequentially run if statements during teleop, and if a button was pressed, a motor would run as long as it was pressed. However, this created a lot of boilerplate and overall made code difficult to maintain as robots grew in complexity. Many teams created their own state machines and other improvements, and WPIlib created the command based paradigm along with a slew of tools to help teams.Command based programming centers around two major abstractions - subsystems and commands. Robots are divided into subsystems - just like how a plane can be divided into engines, control panels (rudder, elevator, and aileron), flaps, and landing gear. These subsystems can only ever be doing one thing at once - they can only be commanded to do one thing at once. These commands are managed by the command scheduler, which interrupts, cancels, and prioritizes new commands. This means that the robot can be doing multiple things at the same time - driving and intaking a game piece, deploying a climb while scoring, following an autonomous path while preparing to score a game piece, etc. These subsystems each have their individual classes, and the RobotContainer class manages the subsystems by sending commands (such as a driver's inputs). This allows for very modular code - subsystems never have to directly interact, which helps with large projects and coding bigger & more complex robots.While the commands are as asynchronous (they don't depend on each other) as possible, the command scheduler still has to run in 20ms loops. This means that if any command takes more than 0.02s to run, the command scheduler overruns and is forced to wait, stalling the next cycle of any command. This can cause significant input lag in the worst case scenario, making the robot undriveable. The more commands that need to be managed, the worse the performance of the scheduler is. However, motors can independently by themselves drive to positions - for example, in the case of Talon/Kraken motors, they can be set to a profile, where they follow a pre-defined movement. This means that you can have "fire and forget" commands, which just set the profile for the motor to follow - which you should do!

Pull Requests are requests that allow for extended discussion and review before doing a merge - you don't have to create pull requests when merging into feature branches, but you do have to create pull requests when merging into Main to request review. You can do this from the GitHub website itself.(the final organization is not set yet, so this is unfilled until we know what we want to do during season) Issues are, obviously, issues, but they can also be for feature requests. 2025-26/chemistry/atom.html.title: Atom
2025-26/chemistry/atom.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-13 An atom is the most basic unit that we usually deal with in chemistry (ahem valenc) First theorized by the Greeks, main proponent of Atomism was Democritus Made up out of electrons, protons, and neutrons Neutrons and protons are roughly the same mass, but neutrons are slightly heavier Electrons are orders of magnitude lighter than protons/neutrons (~1836x) N & P are in the nuclei of the atom Protons are positively charged, electrons negatively charged
Can be represented in a variety of ways, (Bohr Atomic Model or QM Atomic Model)
An Element is determined by the number of protons in an atom A.k.a the atomic number

2025-26/chemistry/bohr-atomic-model.html.title: Bohr Atomic Model
2025-26/chemistry/bohr-atomic-model.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-13
Created by Niehls Bohr in 1913 to explain the emission spectrum of light Pretends electrons are in "orbits" like a planet, easy way to show electrons and shells
While it is outdated (replaced by QM Atomic Model), it had a lot of good ideas Energy levels are quantitized - electrons must be in discrete energy levels Protons and neutrons remain near the center of the atom (nucleus)

2025-26/chemistry/electron-configuration.title: Electron Configuration
2025-26/chemistry/electron-configuration.description:
Tags: #atomic-structure #chemistry Date: 2025-06-13 Good analogy is the idea of a building with floors, apartments, and rooms Shells Individual discrete energy levels (the floors) Subshells A further division of shells Four kinds: , , and Holds 1,3,5, and 7 orbitals respectively Orbitals Each orbital can hold up to 2 electrons In an atom, electrons will occupy the lowest floor first, the smallest apartment, and go one to a room first
Lowest shell --> smallest subshell --> 1/orbital until it's filled (a.k.a Principle of Maximum Multiplicity) Diagram of which subshells get filled first (you may need to use light mode):
Notation:
You can use Arrow Diagrams or by writing the subshells with the current number of electrons as a superscript e.g Notice how the subshell is unfilled, each orbital of the p subshell will only have 1 electron Also, using another element can be used to save time: e.g
The outermost shell (except for period 1) has 8 electrons, which are the Valence Electrons

2025-26/chemistry/element.html.title: Element
2025-26/chemistry/element.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry Date: 2025-06-13
Pure substance, all of its atoms have the same number of protons
Organized via the Periodic Table, which groups the elements by patterns

2025-26/chemistry/periodic-table.html.title: Periodic Table
2025-26/chemistry/periodic-table.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-13 Organizes the elements Bottom number is atomic "weight" (mass), top is atomic number Grouped by columns (groups) and rows (periods)
Groups are also called families due to elements in the same group having similar properties Group IA (leftmost): Alkali Metals, react with water to create alkaline solutions Group IIA (right of alkali metals): Alkaline Earth Metals: oxides create alkaline solutions Group VIIA (left of noble gases): Halogens: "salt-formers", combine with metals to form salts Group VIIIA (rightmost): Noble gases: react with basically nothing Can also be split into metals, metalloids, nonmetals Steplike shift in the atomic table, metals on the left, nonmetals on the right Metals: Lustrous Malleable Ductile Conductors Solid (except for mercury) Nonmetals: Brittle Insulators Mainly gases Metalloids: Don't fall clearly into either category, exhibit properties of metals and non metals

2025-26/chemistry/qm-atomic-model.html.title: QM Atomic Model
2025-26/chemistry/qm-atomic-model.html.description:
Tags: #atomic-structure #chemistry #QM Date: 2025-06-13 The most convoluted explanation of how a model works because QM sucks and is way too complicated (why does the world have to be so weird) Electrons occupy discrete energy levels due to their wavelengths so their energy is quantized However, due to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle, we can never know exactly where the electron is, so the electrons are in electron clouds The discrete energy levels they CAN occupy are called "shells" Each individual "electron cloud" is an orbital These shells are divided into subshells, which contain the same kind of orbitals
See Electron Configuration for more detail
Wave-Particle Duality causes this issue, electrons have properties of particles

2025-26/ap-world/saqs/saqs.html.title: SAQs
2025-26/ap-world/saqs/saqs.html.description: Election Poster for the German National Socialist Party, 1932 The German text in the poster reads, Men! Women! Millions of men without work; millions of children without futures. Save the German familyvote for Adolf Hitler. Using the image, respond to parts a, b, and c. a. Identify ONE likely political purpose of the image. One likely political purpose of the image is to drive the German population to vote for Adolf Hitler and evoke anger, frustration, and hope in the German people. Due to the treaty of Versailles, Germany had to pay expensive war reparations that crippled its economy - thus, the poster hopes to motivate the German population to "save the German family and vote for Adolf Hitler" (even amidst his aggressive views) to rescue them from the poor economic situations b. Explain ONE way the image illustrates the economic situation of the period after the First World War. One way the image illustrates the economic situation of the period after the First World War is in describing the German population as "Millions of men without work, millions of children without futures." This statement, while mildly exaggerated, represents the dire economic situation of Germany after the 1st World War, as the German government could not rebuild critical infrastructure due to extensive war reparations, and the advent of the Great Depression left Germany in a critical state with high unemployment and a weak economy. c. Explain ONE way the rise of the German National Socialist Party led to the Second World War. The rise of the German National Socialist Party was accompanied by increased propaganda and nationalistic sentiment in Germany, that led many Germans into supporting a war and militarization. Nationalism led to a more aggressive Germany that was willing to attack other nations.

2025-26/chemistry/atomic-weight.html.title: Atomic Weight
2025-26/chemistry/atomic-weight.html.description:
Tags: #untagged Date: 2025-06-16 Measured using the Mass Spectrograph (a.k.a mass spectrometer) Created by J. J. Thomson and F. W. Aston Atoms are charged then accelerated in the presence of an EM field.
lighter charges get bent more (slightly similar to refraction in prisms)
Helped facilitate the discovery of Isotopes The spectrometer will show each isotope in their relevant quantities, so the atomic weight is the average of the isotopes in their quantities
Atomic Weight on the Periodic Table is measured in amu (see Units) Fractional due to multiple isotopes Calculated as the weighted average of each naturally occuring isotope's mass For 1 atom only

2025-26/chemistry/covalent-bonding.html.title: Covalent Bonding
2025-26/chemistry/covalent-bonding.html.description:
Tags: #chemical-bonding #chemistry Date: 2025-06-18
Contrasted with Ionic Bonding, where you shed electrons, covalent bonding occurs when atoms share orbitals (share electrons) to get a full outer shell The final compound is made up of molecules, not connected ions (like an ionic crystal) Usually formed between nonmetals
Can be represented with Lewis Diagrams E.g Allows both atoms to maintain a full shell of 8 valenceelectronsAtoms can also share multiple orbitals In the case of Hydrogen, Hydrogen only needs 2 electrons to have a full s shell
Special case is Polar Bonding

2025-26/chemistry/ionic-bonding.html.title: Ionic Bonding
2025-26/chemistry/ionic-bonding.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #chemical-bonding Date: 2025-06-18
Formed when ions of opposite charge attract Metals usually form positive ions, nonmetals negative ions (due to whether they want to shed or gain valence electrons)
Can be with multiple Ions of different charges E.g "Electrostatic bond" or ionic bond One of the strongest kinds of bonds Usually forms ionic crystals, as the bonded ions attract other ions Some exceptions, like Boron Trifluoride () Always written with the most metallic ion first (lowest group)

2025-26/chemistry/ions.html.title: Ions
2025-26/chemistry/ions.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #chemical-bonding Date: 2025-06-18 Formed when a neutral atom gains or loses electrons, thus gaining a charge
In order to maintain a full shell, they can lose or gain Valence Electrons Charge is represented with a superscript (remember electrons are negative) E.g or

2025-26/chemistry/isotopes.html.title: Isotopes
2025-26/chemistry/isotopes.html.description: Tags: #chemistry Date: 2025-06-16 Variations on atoms due to a different number of neutrons Remains in the same proportions in nature (typically) Allows us to calculate the average atomic weight Some isotopes are unstable and decay radioactively

2025-26/chemistry/lewis-diagrams.html.title: Lewis Diagrams
2025-26/chemistry/lewis-diagrams.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-18
Diagrams to represent the valence electrons with dots E.g Hydrogen/Helium can only have 2electrons in their outermost shellNotice that for someelements, due to the principleof maximum multiplicity, youshould fill the s subshell firstwith 2 electrons
Sometimes, you can ignore Principle of Maximum Multiplicity but it won't really be correct

2025-26/chemistry/metallic-bonding.html.title: Metallic Bonding
2025-26/chemistry/metallic-bonding.html.description: Tags: #chemistry #chemical-bonding Date: 2025-06-18 Metallic atoms remain in a 'sea' of electrons and share all valence electrons Technically, they form crystals, as the nuclei get pulled from all directions and are packed together The attraction of the electrons makes them flexible The low electronegativity of the metals means that these atoms are more willing to share electrons, which is why you don't see these kind of interactions in oxygen (as an example)

2025-26/chemistry/polar-bonding.html.title: Polar Bonding
2025-26/chemistry/polar-bonding.html.description:
Tags: #untagged Date: 2025-06-18
Electrons "hug" a certain atom more if the atoms are not identical (see Acids and Bases)
This attraction is called electronegativity Abbr. en In a Lewis Diagram, you represent the electronegativity with Threshold: Covalent if Polar Covalent if Ionic if Depends on shape as well: if the atom is bent/linear >2 atoms Also if the atom is planar or nonplanar

2025-26/chemistry/principle-of-maximum-m.title: Principle of Maximum Multiplicity
2025-26/chemistry/principle-of-maximum-m.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-18 States that each subshell will attempt to have 1 electron to each orbital until you pair with other electrons
Influences Lewis Diagrams

2025-26/chemistry/units.html.title: Units
2025-26/chemistry/units.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry Date: 2025-06-16 Amu "atomic mass unit" 12 amu = 1 neutral carbon atom with 6 neutrons For most problems, assume 1 proton = 1 amu and 1 neutron = 1 amu (since electron is negligble) Gram Atomic Weight
An Atomic Weight in grams will equal the weight of Avogadro's number of atoms So 1g of carbon will have molecules (could be individual atoms) Mole The "Avogadro's number of atoms" is a mole
A mole of anything has molecules (could be individual atoms) and weighs the same as the Atomic Weight expressed in grams.

2025-26/chemistry/valence-electrons.html.title: Valence Electrons
2025-26/chemistry/valence-electrons.html.description:
Tags: #chemistry #atomic-structure Date: 2025-06-18 Electrons in outermost shell in an element
All periods except for period 1 can have 8 electrons in the outermost shell (He and H can only have 2) This tendency is called the octet rule Influences how elements bond All elements attempt to have a full outer shell of electrons to achieve stability
All groups have the same number of valence electrons
Can be represented via Lewis Diagrams Heavily influence bonding

2025-26/chemistry/empirical-formula.html.title: Empirical Formula
2025-26/chemistry/empirical-formula.html.description: Tags: #untagged Date: 2025-07-11 The "simplified" molecular formula, represents the simplest possible chemical formula of an unknown substance Determined via percentage weight analysis Can be converted into the actual formula by comparing the formula weight and the empirical formula weight First, convert to atomic weight, then convert to mols by dividing by the atomic weight --> then divide by the smallest number of mols for each one Given percentage composition, drop the %s and convert it to amu, then progress as normal (divide by atomic weight, etc. etc.)

2025-26/chemistry/formula-&-molecular-we.title: Formula & Molecular Weights
2025-26/chemistry/formula-&-molecular-we.description:
Tags: #untagged Date: 2025-07-11
Molecular weight is the sum of individual atoms inside a molecule (e.g must be Covalent Bonding, not ionic!)
Formula weight denotes the the weight of any combination, whether ionic or covalent, in order to be more general
Both of these are expressed in amu, atomic mass units
Remember that you can convert from amu into g via Avogadro's Number
The Empirical Formula of a molecule is in simplest term, calculated by the ratio of the atoms within a compound

2025-26/chemistry/imfs.html.title: IMFs
2025-26/chemistry/imfs.html.description:
The bond energy is the amount of energy that it takes to pull apart a bond The potential energy is typically negative, meaning that it'll take energy to pull these atoms apart, and is only positive when the atoms experience a repulsive force when they are to close If the atoms are separated, there will never be a positive force due to coulomb's law, only a small negative force A useful analogy is a spring, in it's relaxed state, you can push the spring together to store more potential energy, or pull it apart Bond length is the length of the bonds, influenced by the strength and radii of the atoms
Lattice energy is the energy required to break the ions apart in a crystal lattice Smaller atomic radii = higher strength
Higher difference in charge = higher strength

2025-26/chemistry/ionization-energy-&-el.title: Ionization Energy & Electronegativity
2025-26/chemistry/ionization-energy-&-el.description:
Ionization energy is the measure of how much energy it takes to remove an electron from an atom Similar to electronegativity, the measure of how strong an atom attracts electrons Ionization energy usually scales from left to right in a period, and usually decreases when you move down in a group "Usually" because there are a lot of factors, like electron shielding, etc. etc.
It decreases when when you move down in a group since the radii and thus the strength of attraction decreases Electronegativity is important for predicting what kind of bond is formed

2025-26/chemistry/photoelectron-spectros.title: Photoelectron Spectroscopy
2025-26/chemistry/photoelectron-spectros.description:
aka PES, used to determine the relative energies of electrons in atoms and molecules
Measure the kinetic energies of ejected electrons after irradiating a sample The binding energy can be calculated by the difference between the radiation energy and kinetic energy
Each peak in a PES spectrum corresponds to electrons in different subshells Since the irradiation is random, the peaks will represent on average how many electrons and what energy level they are at

2025-26/english/hunger-(main-story).html.title: Hunger (main story)
2025-26/english/hunger-(main-story).html.description:
Plot: Min is able to leave Taiwan, and has a "yuanfen" ("destined") marriage with Tian, an aspiring violinist who fled China, but Tian's grief over being unable to continue pursuing his music career drives him to force Ruth, the second daughter (1st one, Anna, was tone deaf) into playing music which splits the family apart. Min and Tian gradually lose themselves, while Anna and Ruth find their own paths. What is Lan Samantha Chang trying to show?
The American Dream extends beyond physical success, physical hunger, and is really all about fulfillment, and Lan argues that this lesser-known aspect of the "American dream" is extremely difficult to achieve. The clearest example is Tian - he's unable to achieve what he left China for, to become a violinist, and feels that he gave up his real family for no reason, which is why he forces violin onto Ruth. He pushes his dreams onto Ruth, unable to be satisfied, ignoring everything else for the sake of his dream alone. He doesn't care for Min or Anna, only Ruth, because he grasps at straws to achieve what he came to the U.S for: to be a successful violinist.
Juxtaposed against the grand dreams of Tian is Min, who has no dreams of her own. She is never really an immigrant, but more like a Taiwanese/Chinese living in America. Her lack of dreams is almost like a lack of a future, none of the story centers around her, and she is unable to make any changes. Anna has a similar situation - her past defines her because she has no future.
The entire story center's around Tian's all encompassing dream, and none of the other characters are able to really make decisions until Tian's death, but even after his death Tian influences them all. Ruth is the one most able to leave behind her past, but still she is unfulfilled because she was never loved again by her father. She hates violin because it drove her father away from her. Anna tries to find fulfillment in her past, but she is torn between abandoning everything in her past and trying to keep it. Smaller analysis
If you have it how is it your dream, how are you "hungry".
Tian pushing his "choice" of leaving for music onto Ruth, juxtaposed choice
Diagrhapgm wordplay
Hypocrisy in Min when she sees Anna discussing Asian cultures
Generational trauma that the past and dreams leave behind. Tian's hunger for music outweighs everything else in life, causing him to force his dreams into an unwilling vessel in Ruth as soon as he fails. His desire to perform and succeed in music outweighs music itself, which is shown by his unwillingness to teach music to high schoolers.
Hunger for dreams outweighing physical hunger, characters never fulfilled
Min loses all agency, and is only able to observe. She is not the main character of the story itself due to the lack of her dream to center around.
Content but not satisfied
Ruth unable to let go of the past either
Anna is closest to satisfaction, she is closest to independence
independence is lack of dependence, but also freedom from other chains like the past, problems, etc.
The American Dream is never fulfilled.
Motifs:
Music, children, "family blood", independence, generational trauma, dreams, past
A dream to large too hold, a desire too strong, hunger for too much

2025-26/hmtcs/vector.html.title: Vector
2025-26/hmtcs/vector.html.description:
Vector is abstract, no real representation in reality Physics: arrows with direction, magnitude
CS: list of numbers, n-dimensions for n-entries
Mathematics: two fundamental operations: multiplication and addition (but too abstract) (Almost) always start at origin, list of numbers corresponding to said list are the "steps" across coordinate axis BIJECTIVE - each vector corresponds to 1 point only Scalar multiplication: stretching/scaling vector ("scalar") (y,x) unit vectors respectively Can represent any vector with those two scaled vectors
Form a basis (what scalars scale) Linear combination Span: All vectors you can reach with the linear combination Linearly dependent vector One of the vectors in a set can be represented as the linear combination of another
In the span of another vector Linearly independent

2025-26/math/unit-circle.html.title: Unit Circle
2025-26/math/unit-circle.html.description:
Tags: #math #trig Date: 2025-07-09
Fundamentally, the unit circle is a circle with radius of one Formally, it is the set of all points with an distance of 1 compared to the origin Since , the circumference is , which gives us the radian unit Each coordinate can be solved for using trig, corresponds to the x-coordinate, and corresponds to the y-coordinate.
Gives us some fundamental Trig Identities (This comes directly from the Pythagorean theorem with ) Tangent can be understood as the "slope", Coterminal Angles: Angles that are 360 degrees ( radians) multiples of each other. Subtract 360 until angle < 360. All the trigonometric functions have a period of radians, so all functions repeat e.g Even and Odd Functions: Even: Odd: Cofunctions: - Functions that are equal when you take the complement of one function - are cofunctions

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the closer connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make the graph appear more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar
